section.title: Ctrl-Alt-Del
section.para: When rc is finished starting all those scripts, initinit will continue to read /etc/inittab. The next line is about what to do when the user hits Ctrl-Alt-DeleteCtrl-Alt-Delete on the keyboard.
section.screen: root@barry:~# grep -i ctrl /etc/inittab # What to do when CTRL-ALT-DEL is pressed. ca:12345:ctrlaltdel:/sbin/shutdown -t1 -a -r now
section.para: Which is very similar to the default Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5.2 action.
section.screen: [root@RHEL52 ~]# grep -i ctrl /etc/inittab # Trap CTRL-ALT-DELETE ca::ctrlaltdel:/sbin/shutdown -t3 -r now
section.para: The details of the shutdown will be discussed later in this chapter.

section.title: UPS and loss of power
section.screen: [root@RHEL52 ~]# grep ^p /etc/inittab pf::powerfail:/sbin/shutdown -f -h +2 "Power Failure; System Shutting Down" pr:12345:powerokwait:/sbin/shutdown -c "Power Restored; Shutdown Cancelled"
section.para: It will read commands on what to execute in case of powerfailure, powerok and Ctrl-Alt-DeleteCtrl-Alt-Delete. The init process never stops keeping an eye on power failures and that triple key combo.
section.screen: root@barry:~# grep ^p /etc/inittab pf::powerwait:/etc/init.d/powerfail start pn::powerfailnow:/etc/init.d/powerfail now po::powerokwait:/etc/init.d/powerfail stop

section.title: Display the runlevel
section.para: You can see your current runlevel with the runlevelrunlevel(1) or who -rwho -r commands.
The runlevel command is typical linux and will output the previous and the current runlevel. If there was no previous runlevel, then it will mark it with the letter N.
The history of who -r dates back to older unixes, and it still works on linux.

section.title: Changing the runlevel
section.para: You can switch to another runlevel with the telinittelinit(1) command. On Linux /sbin/telinit/sbin/telinit is usually a hard link to /sbin/init.
